Thibault, who also publishes a newsletter on cheating called This Isn’t Fine, said he thinks students would be better off ensuring they have a record of their revision history in Google Docs or Microsoft Word than using a humanizer. But ultimately, he believes, the shift that’s coming is moving toward more monitoring of students completing assignments.

“I think we have to ask students, what level of surveillance are you willing to subject yourself to so that we can actually know that you’re learning?” he said. “There is a new agreement that needs to be made.”
Students surveilling themselves

Superhuman, the company that makes Grammarly, developed a tool it calls Authorship that’s included with basic accounts. Students can turn it on to surveil themselves on Google Docs or Microsoft Word as they write and playback later. It will show which sections were typed, pasted from another source or generated with AI.

“We’re going to keep track of when you are going to Wikipedia,” said Jenny Maxwell, Superhuman’s head of education. “We’re going to keep track of when Grammarly is making suggestions and you’re taking them, we’re going to keep track of how much time you’ve spent in this paper or how many sessions.”
As many as 5 million Authorship reports were created in the past year alone, she said, though most of the time they aren’t submitted.

Maxwell said the tool was inspired by a viral TikTok video from Marley Stevens, who described the havoc of what she said was a false accusation of AI use that landed her on academic probation in 2023 at the University of North Georgia. In reality, Stevens said, she’d only used Grammarly’s extension to help fix spelling and punctuation.

The university declined to comment on Stevens’ case, citing federal privacy law, but said in a statement that “faculty communicate specific guidelines regarding the use of AI for various classes and those guidelines are included in the class syllabi.”

Stevens, who graduated last month, said it was difficult to keep track of each professor’s policy around AI usage — and it increasingly became hard to avoid writing on software that didn’t have it embedded.

“Google has AI embedded into it, Microsoft has AI embedded into it — like literally everything has AI in it,” she said. “So, in a roundabout way, there’s no way to write a paper without using AI, unless you go to the library and you check books out and use encyclopedias.”
Pressure on colleges

Some students believe universities should stop using AI detectors because of false positives. In upstate New York, an online petition calling on the University at Buffalo to drop the software received more than 1,500 signatures last year.

Kelsey Auman, who graduated last spring, started the petition after she fought to prove she did not use AI on several of her assignments. She knew enough classmates with similar experiences that they had a group chat named “Academic Felons for Life.” Auman said she started to run her papers through multiple AI detectors on her own before turning them in, hoping to avoid another dispute, but it created more anxiety when they also incorrectly flagged things she wrote as generated by a chatbot.
“So it’s like, how far do you want to go down the rabbit hole? I’m making myself crazy,” she said.
"We keep turning on what the academic institutions need to do to fix problems that they didn’t create."
Tricia Bertram Gallant, director of academic integrity at UC San Diego
The University at Buffalo said it does not have an institutionwide rule on AI use, but instructors must have evidence beyond a detector score to report a student for academic dishonesty.

Tricia Bertram Gallant, director of the academic integrity office at UC San Diego, advises faculty to realize how herculean of a task it is to ensure students don’t use AI if they aren’t completing the work in front of them.
“If it’s an unsupervised assessment, don’t bother trying to ban AI,” she said. “And don’t bother trying to prove AI was used because you end up spending more time doing that.”

But Bertram Gallant, who is also president emeritus of the International Center for Academic Integrity, wishes more people would put pressure on the government to regulate AI and the academic cheating industry, and on tech companies to make it harder for students to use their products to cheat.
“We keep turning on what the academic institutions need to do to fix problems that they didn’t create,” she said.

title: Western states face 'snow drought' as snowpack hits record lows
summary: The recent winter storm did not alleviate the "snow drought" plaguing Colorado, Utah and other western states. Snowpack levels are far below average in many regions.
story: Last weekend’s winter storm may have covered much of the country in a glut of snow and ice, but the season has not delivered out West, where several states face a snowpack drought.
In Colorado, the snowpack is “the lowest on record for this point in the season,” said Peter Goble, the assistant state climatologist. “All of our mountain ranges are well below normal.”
It’s the same story in Utah.
“We’re in uncharted territory right now, and we’re headed toward the lowest snowpack we’ve ever had on Feb. 1,” said Kevin Perry, a University of Utah atmospheric scientist.

Given those conditions, scientists are growing concerned about the water supply and a risk of wildfires later in the year. Because the mountain snowpack in Western states runs off as water throughout spring and summer, the levels influence how much water farmers can use to irrigate crops, how risky the wildfire season will be, and how much electricity hydropower dams can generate.

Measurements of Western snowpack come from the National Resources Conservation Service, which collects data from more than 800 high-elevation monitoring stations in the mountains. The service tracks how much water is in the snowpack at more than 80 basins in the Western continental United States, and its data shows that all but a handful are trending well below average.
While it’s not unusual to have some basins lower than historical averages, it’s rare to have nearly every region of the West facing snowfall deficits.
In Washington state, a mid-January climb of Mount Saint Helens revealed conditions that felt more like June than midwinter, with large patches of volcanic rock exposed near the crater rim.

The reasons for the snowpack drought vary by region, but across the West, temperatures have been uncommonly warm this winter, which has led more precipitation to fall as rain instead of snow. That was true when atmospheric river storms hammered the Pacific Northwest in December.

“Washington, Oregon, California and many Western states had their warmest December ever on record, and so the torrential rains that we had with the atmospheric river and the flooding and damage from too much water — none of that stayed in the mountains,” said Philip Mote, a professor at Oregon State University’s College of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences.
Then this month, the spigot of moisture largely shut off in the Northwest.
In Utah, early season rainfall in November and December melted everything below about 9,000 feet of elevation, leaving the Wasatch mountains looking top heavy, according to Perry.
“The high elevation snowpack is actually really good,” Perry said. But “we just have no low elevation and very little mid-elevation snowpack.”
Colorado has simply remained relatively hot and dry.
“December of 2025 was nine degrees warmer than average statewide, which was our warmest on record, going back to 1895,” Goble said.
The snowpack in California — known for its boom and bust water cycle — is in better shape, particularly in the southern Sierras, where several basins have above-average accumulations.
But for the regions left wanting for snow, little relief is expected soon.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s Climate Prediction Center expects dry conditions for much of the West for the next two weeks, with temperatures remaining above average for the next month.
Mote said some areas west of the Cascade crest — which runs up the spine of Washington and Oregon — could recover if a few big storms come later this winter or in spring.
But, he said, “for Eastern Washington and most of Idaho, the story’s already kind of been written and it’s just unlikely to change.”

Scientists have struggled to quantify the influence of climate change on snowpack, since warming is both raising temperatures and shifting patterns of precipitation. Trends in snowpack are also heavily influenced by natural variability. However, research published in 2024 in the journal Nature found that climate change was to blame for a declining trend in snowpack across the Northern Hemisphere.
Mote’s work in the Western U.S. shows dramatic declines.
“The story just keeps getting clearer and sadder,” he said.

If the low snowpack continues, it will add pressure to already tense negotiations between seven Western states over how to split up flows from the Colorado River, which provides drinking water to 40 million people. The river’s flow has dwindled as a result of long-term drought and because its users collectively have rights to take more water each year than is actually available.

The Bureau of Reclamation earlier this month released its draft of how to manage the water, which supports 5.5 million acres of agriculture and hydropower operations in California, Arizona, Nevada, Colorado, New Mexico, Utah and Wyoming.

The states are negotiating a long-term plan for how to manage the river’s water and prevent dams at Lake Mead and Lake Powell from reaching “dead pool” status, when flow would be cut off to lower regions of the river. But those negotiations have reportedly been at a standstill.
“In the short run, having a low snowpack year may raise the urgency of coming to some of those agreements,” Goble said.

title: ‘Shrinking’ Stars Reflect on Returning to Altadena for Season 3 After LA Fires
summary: “Shrinking” is back for its third season. Read what the stars told TODAY.com about filming on location following the devastating Los Angeles fires.
story: “Shrinking” is back for its third season, and the return of the Apple TV show has some feeling nostalgic.

The series follows grieving therapist Jimmy (Jason Segel) after the death of his wife. Meanwhile, his teenage daughter Alice (Lukita Maxwell) navigates the loss of her mother, too. As the seasons continue, the poignant show also tackles the progression of Dr. Paul's (Harrison Ford) Parkinson’s disease and how all the characters come together to take care of each other. (Ahead of its Jan. 27 Season 3 premiere, the Apple TV show was already renewed for a fourth season.)
Season 3 may be especially noteworthy and emotional for residents of Altadena and Pasadena, who were affected by the Eaton Fire that erupted on Jan. 7, 2025.

Nineteen people died, thousands were displaced and 9,418 homes and other buildings were destroyed when the Eaton Canyon caught on fire during 90 miles per hour winds, according to The Associated Press. At the same time, the Palisades Fire on the opposite side of town was also ablaze and destructive.
“Shrinking” is filmed in Los Angeles and highlights special landmarks in the Pasadena and Altadena communities.

Locations like Gaby’s (Jessica Williams) home in Altadena, where they shoot exterior shots, was burned down. Eaton Canyon, where the fire ignited, is also used as a hiking location for the show. Jimmy and Alice's home, which is right next to Liz (Christa Miller) and Derek's (Ted McGinley)'s house, is located on the cusp of Pasadena and Altadena.

Altadena staple Charles S. Farnsworth Park, where the crew is seen playing pickleball and roaming the park, was also deeply impacted when the William D. Davies Memorial Building was destroyed. A year after the fires, the park has yet to be reopened or rebuilt.
TODAY.com spoke with the stars of the Emmy-nominated show about their experience returning to the set of “Shrinking” following the devastating fire.
The below has been edited and condensed for clarity.
Jessica Williams

I always think about what Mr. Rogers said, where he’s like, “Look for the helpers in the time of disaster.” And to me, with both fires, especially being from LA, it was just devastating. To be able to go back and hire locally and be in local places, donate and give time, that was a big, big part of my personal journey when shooting the show.

I think we were supposed to start shooting the week of the fires. So we had to push and then we had to do all the interior (shots). I know the homeowners of my character’s house. It burned down. So Gaby’s house burned down — so we just shot (it on a sound stage) — which is so, so sad. There was a bit of fear of wanting to get it right and figuring out how to play the show with the fires and just choosing to kind of move forward on the show. I was really nervous about it.

There were so many starts and stops because we couldn’t shoot outside in the area, especially at Jimmy and Liz’s house with the air quality, which is in Pasadena. As someone who lives in Eagle Rock, the best part is shooting in our community and area, and it was just really sad. All the actors felt it. A few of the actors weren’t in their homes and some of the crew lost their homes. But (we were like), we got to make money. At that point, there’s only like, five projects going in LA. There’s not a lot that shoots in LA. We’re starting to get that back, but it was just sad and it was kind of just the backdrop of the whole show.
Lukita Maxwell

I live not too far and it was a very difficult time. We didn’t go back on location for a while. We were just waiting to make sure that the location was clear and safe for everybody to go to and that everybody there was safe. I remember the first drive back onto the set and — as it is with, I think, all of these areas in LA that were affected and touched by this crazy fire — the energy of the Earth changed. So there was a lot of energy on that drive. I remember feeling very grateful that I was and my loved ones were safe. It was a hard time.
Michael Urie

I was so, so sad about Altadena when we started shooting last season and so much of it was gone. So many people were displaced. And our sweet locations, we have a lot of locations in Altadena, and luckily, almost all of them were OK. Going back there was very moving for all of us because we couldn’t for a while. We had to postpone a lot of those scenes for the end of the shoot, but being back there was quite moving.

(Before “Shrinking”), I didn’t know about this neighborhood. I had slept on Altadena. It was like this magical little jewel in the Los Angeles neighborhood spectrum that had slipped past me. It is really lovely there, and I’m so glad that we got to bring some life and some money back to the community. It’s become just a beautiful location for our show. I think we’ve gotten to give a face to a name to a lot of people that might not know that community.
Ted McGinley
I lived in the Palisades, so we’re not in our house either. We moved out to Altadena, where we film, and we couldn’t go there because the houses were being remediated. Thank God, they made it.

We’re very proud of how we represent Pasadena, Altadena. It’s a great community. They’ve opened their doors to us and we try to respect it. And you see it in the show, we show the best parts of it and it’s a great background. We had to wait to get into our houses, so we did the interiors. And then when we shot the exteriors, we did all of the (scenes). We did like six, seven shows in one week, in the back, in the outside. But we couldn’t get in for months, we were behind... It was really tricky, but it was a fun challenge. We love the people of Pasadena, Altadena.
Luke Tennie

(Returning to Altadena and Pasadena) felt great — and let me explain why. In my light research, I’ve learned how beneficial it can be to work in places that have experienced natural disasters. I grew up in South Florida, so our disasters look different, a lot of hurricanes and rain and tropical storms. There’d be a lot of damage there. But the most important thing about where we live is what takes place here. The industry that makes a lot of the money here is film and TV. So the more that we can shoot in these locations, the more we can nurse them back to health. “Shrinking” is a Pasadena show. It’s an Altadena show. It takes place there. The more we can actually operate there and create work there, and bring revenue and jobs there, the better the place will be. So I hope that we can do, I don’t know, maybe about 87 or 89 more seasons of “Shrinking,” to be specific. I think that’ll all just help the city out in terms of growing and repairing the damage that was done.

title: ‘The Pitt’s’ Gerran Howell Was ‘Peer Pressured’ into Pranking George Clooney — and Is ‘Terrified’ for Him to Find Out
summary: “The Pitt” star Gerran Howell is owning up to a prank he pulled on George Clooney — and is sharing why he is “terrified” for the Oscar winner to learn he was the culprit.
story: “The Pitt” star Gerran Howell is owning up to a prank he pulled on George Clooney — and is sharing why he is “terrified” for the Oscar winner to learn he was the culprit.

Howell, who portrays Dr. Dennis Whitaker on the hit HBO medical drama, appeared on the 3rd Hour of TODAY Jan. 28 to discuss the new season. During his chat with Al Roker, Emilie Ikeda and Craig Melvin, Howell also spoke about how he and “The Pitt” co-star Noah Wyle both previously worked with Clooney.

While Wyle and Clooney shared the screen during their “ER” days, Howell teamed up with the “Jay Kelly” star more recently when they starred together in the miniseries “Catch-22,” which was released in 2019.
When Al asked the Welsh actor about Clooney directing a couple “Catch-22” episodes, the TODAY co-host mentioned that he heard Howell participated in a prank on set.
“Oh, dear. Well, I was peer pressured into it may I first say,” Howell replied. “It was ‘Catch-22,’ so we were working on an Air Force base in Italy, and we had bikes to get around everywhere.”

“We went to a supermarket, and there were My Little Pony bike accessories. And someone said, ‘Wouldn’t that be funny if you put some glittery streamers on George’s bike one lunchtime and a lovely pink bell?’” he recalled. “So I did that, and then I remember riding onto set, and he had clearly ripped them off.”
Howell continued, “Nothing was said about it, so I am terrified that maybe my life is I’m just waiting for him (to find out).
The 34-year-old said he had never publicly shared the story, so Clooney didn’t know he was behind the prank … until now.
“Your first and last time working with George Clooney," Craig joked.
Howell responded, “There we go. Exactly,” as he laughed.

In “Catch-22,” which was based on the 1961 novel of the same name by Joseph Heller, Howell portrayed Kid Sampson in five episodes. Clooney only appeared in three episodes as Scheisskopf, however, he also directed two episodes and served as an executive producer on the series.

title: Kim Kardashian Explains Why Pics of Meghan and Harry Were Deleted From Kris Jenner's Birthday Party
summary: Kim Kardashian has shared the stories behind "Photogate" involving Prince Harry and Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, at her mom Kris Jenner's 70th birthday bash.
story: Kim Kardashian has shared the stories behind "Photogate" involving Prince Harry and Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, at her mom Kris Jenner's 70th birthday bash.

The fashion mogul and reality star spoke to sister Khloe Kardashian on her "Khloé In Wonder Land" podcast released on Jan. 28 about why Kim Kardashian and Jenner deleted photos of the royal couple from the party that they had shared on Instagram in November. The sisters dubbed it "Photogate."
"It was really innocent, which is so crazy," Kim Kardashian said.

She said Jenner and the former Meghan Markle have been friends for years and have "a really sweet relationship," which led to Meghan and Harry being on the guest list with the likes of Mariah Carey and Oprah Winfrey for Jenner's star-studded birthday party.
Kim Kardashian said she asked the royal couple if it was OK to post photos of them from the night.
"We’re all communicating about like what we’re going to post," Kardashian said. "We’re never ones to post without permission. That's not who we are."

She said they initially received permission, but then requested they be taken down. The photos were posted around the time of Remembrance Day, a British memorial day that honors military veterans who have died in the line of duty. Prince Harry is a British military veteran himself.

"We were told that it was totally cool to post, and then after it was posted, I think they realized it was Remembrance Day, and they didn’t want to be seen at a party even though it’s already up, you know, and then taken down," Kardashian said. "And then I think they realized like, 'Ugh, this was so silly.'"
The royal couple had also attended the Baby2Baby gala event earlier that night to support the charity event in which their friend, tennis legend Serena Williams, was honored with an award.
"It's like a charity event, so like that was fine, but maybe not partying and dancing on the dance floor (at Jenner's party)," Kardashian said. "We took them down to respect Remembrance Day."
Jenner posted a carousel of photos on Instagram featuring many of the celebrity guests, but Harry and Meghan were absent.
Kardashian seemed to see the scrutiny over the deleted photos as an overblown issue.
"You've just got to laugh at the situation sometimes and just like lighten it up," she said. "If everyone’s taking it the wrong way like lean in."
She suggested they should've made it into a bit for her undergarment company.

"I was like we should do a full Skims campaign, take the photo, post it and then delete it 30 minutes later and say, 'Oh, sorry. I didn’t have permission to post those photos for the campaign,'" she said. "That would have hit so funny if we just made it light and made it funny. I think it would've been received differently.
"But I hated how that was received for everyone," she continued. "It was just made into something that was so crazy and ridiculous that didn't have to be."
TODAY.com has reached out to the Sussexes for comment and has not heard back by the time of publication.

title: Serena Williams Has Cheeky Reaction When Asked If She's Returning to Tennis
summary: Is Serena Williams returning to tennis? Here's how she responded when asked about her retirement plans during a TODAY interview.
story: Is the greatest women's tennis player of all time considering a return to the sport?
Serena Williams, who stepped away from the sport in 2022, wasn't about to give that away on TODAY on Jan. 28, but she didn't say no, either.
"I mean really, are you asking this on the TODAY show?" she told Savannah Guthrie. "Oh my God."
"They would kill me if I didn't," Savannah replied.

Williams, 44, raised some eyebrows in December when she filed the necessary paperwork to return to the sport's registered drug-testing pool. With speculation building at that time, she tweeted, "Omg yall I’m NOT coming back. This wildfire is crazy."
On TODAY, she was not that definitive.
"Oh my goodness," she said.
"Is that a no?" Savannah asked.
"Is that a no?" Williams responded. "Now people on the set are laughing, this is distracting. You're distracting us over there."
"OK, but you didn't say yes or no," Savannah said.
"I'm just having fun and enjoying my life right now," Williams replied.
"That's not a yes or a no," Savannah clarified.
"That's not a yes or a no," Williams said. "I don't know, I'm just going to see what happens."
Savannah stayed on the case.
"That's a maybe to me," she said.
"That's not a maybe," Williams replied. "Listen, I have two kids. I am a full-time stay-at-home (mom). When I filled out a form the other day, occupation: housewife."
Savannah followed by noting that Williams re-entered the drug protocol, a precursor for any type of comeback by the 23-time Grand Slam winner.

There also was conjecture that she would return because her sister, fellow tennis luminary Venus Williams, was back on the court at 45, where she recently became the oldest woman to compete in the singles draw at the Australian Open.
"Did I re-enter?" Williams coyly said about the drug protocol. "I didn't know if I was out. Listen, I can't discuss this."
"I'm just saying that if you wanted to put it to bed, this would be a good moment to put the retirement rumors to bed," Savannah said.
"I want to go to bed," Williams said while laughing. "It's early. You're funny. That was fun."
Craig Melvin was unconvinced, as he said from off camera that he "heard a maybe."
"You didn't hear a maybe," Williams said.

Williams played her final match in September 2022 after participating in her final Grand Slam event at that year's U.S. Open. She shared in an essay for Vogue at that time that she was choosing motherhood over continuing her career.
She is a mom to daughters Olympia, 8, and Adira, 2, with husband Alexis Ohanian.

Williams also spoke to Savannah about Venus' wedding over the holidays and her upcoming Super Bowl commercial for Ro, a health care company connected to a GLP-1 medication that she says has transformed her health. Williams' husband, Alexis Ohanian, is an investor in Ro and serves on the board.

title: A Kentucky Derby-Inspired Movie Filmed at Churchill Downs Is Coming to Hallmark
summary: Hallmark is teaming up with Churchill Downs to make a Kentucky Derby-inspired movie filmed at the historic racetrack. Everything you need to know.
story: Hallmark has revealed it is teaming up with Churchill Downs to make a Kentucky Derby-inspired movie filmed at the historic racetrack.

The network shared exclusively with TODAY that its new original film, “Kentucky Roses,” will honor the “pageantry, tradition, and enduring spirit of the Kentucky Derby.” The movie will premiere on Hallmark Saturday, May 2, the same day of the 2026 Kentucky Derby. The sporting event is famously held the first Saturday in May every year at Churchill Downs.
“Kentucky Roses,” which will also stream the next day on Hallmark+, will star Andrew Walker and Odette Annable, as well as Ally Ledford, Peyton Meyer, Brynn Thayer and Gregg Henry.

The film’s storyline will take place across two timelines. Sadie Moore, played by Annable, will be at the center of the story in present day. She works at a Churchill Downs greenhouse and dreams of becoming a florist and following in her great-grandmother’s (Ledford) footsteps by supplying the Derby with a display of roses. Sadie then meets Ash Taylor, Walker’s character, who is the son of the Churchill Downs CEO (Henry). Ash has to repair one of the racetrack’s iconic Twin Spires after it is damaged in a storm.
Sadie and Ash develop a connection, but it could be cut short after they discover “a bittersweet love story from the past that threatens to repeat itself.”

Speaking about the collaboration between Hallmark and Churchill Downs, Jessica Callahan, vice president at Hallmark Media, said in part, “Together, we’re thrilled to bring audiences an inspiring story of community, courage and time-honored traditions.”

Along with the romantic flick, Hallmark and Churchill Downs are also partnering to release a collection of jewelry inspired by “Kentucky Roses.” The jewelry will be sold in Hallmark Gold Crown stores.

title: The Real-Life Love Story That Inspired Alex Warren's 'Ordinary'
summary: What is the meaning of Alex Warren's song "Ordinary"? Here's how his wife inspired the hit song.
story: Alex Warren turned everyday love into the hit song "Ordinary."
Released in February 2025, the song was practically everywhere in 2025, topping Billboard's Hot 100 and being named as Billboard's 2025 song of the summer. This is Warren's first No. 1 hit song.
Warren debuted his first album, "You’ll Be Alright, Kid," on July 18 with feature tracks from Jelly Roll and BLACKPINK singer ROSÉ.
Going into the new year, Warren reached a new milestone in 2026: his first Grammy nomination for best new artist. He will also perform at the award show on Feb. 1.

The 24-year-old did it all with the woman who inspired the song by his side. Warren tied the knot with YouTuber Kouvr Annon in 2024. At that point, couple had been together for four years. Warren decided to pursue a career in music after they both left Hype House, a content creator house.
Annon appears in the music video for the song, which shows him following her through a wooded landscape.
Below, find more about the meaning of "Ordinary," and be prepared with tissues.
The Meaning Behind the Lyrics of 'Ordinary'
"Ordinary" is a pop ballad about being deeply in love.

Warren makes his heavy emotions clear early on in the song as he sings, "Oh, my, my love/ I take one look at you/ You’re takin’ me out of the ordinary/ I want you layin’ me down ‘til we’re dead and buried."
The song uses spiritual imagery and metaphors to describe the experience. In an interview with HITS, Warren said as he is a Christian and often uses biblical references in his music.
The chorus goes, "The angels up in the clouds are jealous knowin’ we found/Hopeless hallelujah/On this side of Heaven’s gate...At your altar, I will pray."

As the song continues, Warren sings about how out of the ordinary this life-changing love is: "World was in black and white until I saw your light/I thought you had to die to find/Somethin’ so out of the ordinary."
Warren shared on Instagram that he wrote the song about his wife.
"I wrote ordinary about my wife, my best friend," he wrote. "It’s crazy to think that we’ve been together for almost 7 years."
“This song is now number 1 everywhere and I can’t help but smile to know it’s about you,” Warren wrote. “It also reminds me that we’ve been together this long and I’ve never seen you run full speed.”
Warren told the music publication HITS more about the origin story of the song, which he co-wrote with Adam Yaron, Cal Shapiro and Mags Duval.

“We wrote that record about my relationship with my wife, Kouvr. We’re both 24, we met when we were 18, she slept in a car with me. I think it’s rare today to find true love, with phones and social media and all these different things. And so we wrote ‘Ordinary’ about how love is falling out, but we found something crazy,” he said.
In a TikTok video, Warren gently roasted Annon for not knowing the lyrics to the song. "I thought the lyrics said, 'And I'll my life I'll do ya,'" she said in the video.
“I thought you were talking about getting freaky, and I was, like, ‘Damn, my mom listens to this,’” she continued.
The real lyrics go, “Oh, my life, how do ya?/ Breathe and take my breath away?”
Read “Ordinary” lyrics in full below.
Read the Lyrics of 'Ordinary' in Full
They say, “The holy water’s watered down
And this town’s lost its faith
Our colors will fade eventually.”
So, if our time is runnin’ out
Day after day
We’ll make the mundane our masterpiece
Oh, my, my
Oh, my, my love
I take one look at you
You’re takin’ me out of the ordinary
I want you layin’ me down ‘til we’re dead and buried
On the edge of your knife, stayin’ drunk on your vine
The angels up in the clouds are jealous knowin’ we found
Somethin’ so out of the ordinary
You got me kissin’ thе ground of your sanctuary
Shatter me with your touch, oh, Lord, return mе to dust
The angels up in the clouds are jealous knowin’ we found
Hopeless hallelujah
On this side of Heaven’s gate
Oh, my life, how do ya
Breathe and take my breath away?
At your altar, I will pray
You’re the sculptor, I’m the clay
Oh, my, my
You’re takin’ me out of the ordinary
I want you layin’ me down ‘til we’re dead and buried
On the edge of your knife, stayin’ drunk on your vine
The angels up in the clouds are jealous knowin’ we found
Somethin’ so out (Out) of the ordinary (Ordinary)
You got me kissing the ground (Ground) of your sanctuary (Sanctuary)
Shatter me with your touch, oh, Lord, return me to dust
The angels up in the clouds are jealous knowin’ we found
Somethin’ so heavenly, higher than ecstasy
Whenever you’re next to me, oh, my, my
World was in black and white until I saw your light
I thought you had to die to find
Somethin’ so out of the ordinary
I want you laying me down ‘til we’re dead and buried
On the edge of your knife, stayin’ drunk on your vine
The angels up in the clouds are jealous knowin’ we found
Somethin’ so out (Out) of the ordinary
You got me kissing the ground (Ground) of your sanctuary (Sanctuary)
Shatter me with your touch, oh, Lord, return me to dust
The angels up in the clouds are jealous knowin’ we found

title: Who Is Performing at the 2026 Grammys?
summary: Who is performing at the 2026 Grammys? Here's a list of everyone performing from Sabrina Carpenter to Pharrell Williams to best new artists like Olivia Dean.
story: Who is performing at the 2026 Grammys? The entire best new artist category, that's who.
As the Feb. 1 award ceremony approaches, the Recording Academy has been releasing the names of the performers viewers can expect to see take the stage at Crypto.com Arena in Los Angeles.

So far, the Recording Academy confirmed that all eight best new artist nominees will perform as part of a special segment. This will be the second year in a row that every artist in the category will sing.

So, who are all the best new artist nominees this year, and what other major artists have also been revealed as performers? Read on to learn everything you need to know about the 2026 Grammys performances, below.
Sabrina Carpenter

After gracing the stage last year to perform a medley of her hits “Espresso” and “Please Please Please,” Carpenter is back to sing songs from latest album, “Man’s Best Friend.” The Recording Academy announced Carpenter as the first performer this year.
Carpenter is already a two-time Grammy winner after receiving golden gramophones in 2025 for best pop vocal album for “Short n’ Sweet” and best pop solo performance for “Espresso.”

When the 2026 Grammy nominations were revealed in November, Carpenter received six nods in categories like album of the year, song of the year and record of the year. Fans will have to tune in on Feb. 1 to find out if she adds more Grammy wins to her resume.
Clipse and Pharrell Williams
Clipse, a hip-hop duo nominated for five Grammys this year, will team up with Pharrell Williams for an epic performance.

Williams, a 13-time Grammy winner, received four nods. Clipse — who consists of Gene “Malice” and Terrence “Pusha T” Thornton — and Williams collaborated on “Let God Sort Em Out,” which is nominated for album of the year and best rap album.
They also worked together on the track “The Birds Don’t Sing,” up for best rap song, and “Chains & Whips,” a best rap performance nominee.
Best New Artists
All of the best new artist nominees are performing at the 2026 Grammys. The list includes:
After getting her start on TikTok, Addison Rae released her self-titled debut album, “Addison,” in June 2025. The album includes hits like “Fame is a Gun” and “Diet Pepsi.”

Alex Warren began his career by sharing his music on YouTube and TikTok before his song “Ordinary” became a huge success last year. The song, which landed on top of the Billboard Hot 100 chart, was the lead single from his debut studio album, “You’ll Be Alright Kid.”

Girl group Katseye, with members Daniela Avanzini, Lara Raj, Manon Bannerman, Megan Skiendiel, Sophia Laforteza and Yoonchae Jeong, was formed on the 2023 reality competition show “Dream Academy.” The following year, the group released singles, “Debut” and “Touch,” and have skyrocketed since then. Their second EP, “Beautiful Chaos,” arrived in June 2025 and featured hits like “Gnarly” and “Gabriela.”

Leon Thomas, whose fans have followed his journey since his “Victorious” days, is already a Grammy winner thanks to SZA’s hit “Snooze,” which he co-wrote and won best R&B song at the 2024 Grammys. Now, he has received six Grammy nominations for his album “MUTT.” In addition to best new artist, he is also vying for best R&B album, best traditional R&B performance, best R&B song, best R&B performance and album of the year.

Oliva Dean has fans crooning along to her music all year long. The British breakout star achieved global success last year thanks to her earworms “Man I Need” and “So Easy (To Fall in Love).” Both songs are from her second album, “The Art of Loving,” which has steadily been climbing its way up the Billboard 200 chart. In November, Dean was the musical guest on “Saturday Night Live.”

Alternative artist Sombr, who is also a record producer, has an MTV Video Music Award and is looking to add a Grammy to his collection of trophies. Last year, he released his debut studio album, “I Barely Know Her,” with the hits “Back to Friends” and “Undressed.” The music video for “Back to Friends” earned him a VMA for best alternative video.

Bilingual pop band The Marías — lead singer María Zardoya, drummer Josh Conway, guitarist Jesse Perlman and keyboardist Edward James — has been making music for around a decade. But, their breakout moment came in 2022 when they were featured on Bad Bunny’s song “Otro Atardecer.” Then, their song “No One Noticed” from their second album, “Submarine,” went viral. In 2025, the group also worked with Selena Gomez and Benny Blanco on the song “Ojos Tristes” from the couple’s joint album.

British artist Lola Young, who recently took a break from performing to focus on her health, is the final best new artist nominee. Her song “Messy” from the 2024 album “This Wasn’t Meant for You Anyway” went viral on TikTok after years of making music. She performed the hit on “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon” in January 2025. She was also featured on fellow 2026 Grammy nominee Tyler, the Creator’s song “Like Him” from his album “Chromakopia.”

title: Chrissy Teigen Reveals the 'Quiet' Warning Signs She Was Drinking Too Much Alcohol
summary: Chrissy Teigen says she has quit alcohol again after becoming concerned she was drinking too much. She reveals the "quiet" signs that concerned her.
story: Chrissy Teigen says she has quit alcohol again after becoming concerned she was drinking too much.
“We aren’t talking the kind of drinking where you slur your words and miss a step on the stairs. It was just quiet and consistent,” Teigen, 40, revealed in a post on Instagram on Tuesday, Jan. 27.
The model and cookbook author has now been sober for more than 50 days, she wrote.
She first took a break from drinking in 2020, then celebrated a year without alcohol in 2022.
But in the spring of 2025, Teigen said she let alcohol back into her life.
“I promised myself it would be in a ‘mindful’ way. I wanted to be able to have a glass of wine on a date night with my husband. To be able to toast on birthdays,” she wrote in her post this week.
“Soon it became the kind of drinking I’m all too familiar with. Quiet moments at home were for wine.”
Teigen noticed that she began to drink earlier and earlier in the day, first starting at 6 p.m. then eventually at lunch. “When it got to 11am, I was like, oh f--k, here we go again,” she wrote.
The day drinking meant she wasn’t able to pick up her car keys for a last-minute grocery run, she added, another troubling sign. And she didn't feel good about herself.

Still, it wasn’t “messy enough yet to stop,” Teigen said. What made the difference was a conversation on her "Self-Conscious" podcast with “Summer House” star Carl Radke about his own journey with sobriety.
She was also in talks to appear on the “Star Search” reboot and vowed there'd be "absolutely no f-----g way I’d do it with alcohol in my dressing room."
Teigen said she has no desire to turn back and return to drinking alcohol.
“Turns out, without it, I can still be funny. Still be stupid. Still be wildly nervous. Anxious," she wrote. "And I can get through it all without it.”

title: Ben Stiller and Benson Boone Are an Unlikely Duo in Instacart’s Super Bowl Commercial
summary: Ben Stiller and Benson Boone play brothers in an '80s-style Europop band in a Super Bowl ad for Instacart, directed by Spike Jonze.
story: Ben Stiller goes bananas in every comedic role he embodies, but this time, it’s little more literal.

The “Zoolander” actor and “Severance” director teamed up with the “Mystical Magical” singer with more flips than a home-design show, Benson Boone, for Instacart’s Super Bowl commercial. The vintage-style spot, entitled “Bananas,” was directed by Spike Jonze, who directed the movies “Her,” “Being John Malkovich” and a plethora of iconic music videos.

“What was fun about it, to me, was committing to a very specific world and, comedically, it’s fun to jump into something like that,” Stiller tells TODAY.com, adding that the combination of working with Boone and Jonze — whom he calls “one of our great American directors” — sounded really exciting to him.

“I’ve known Spike for a long time, but we never worked together, and I knew that if Spike was doing it, he was going to dial it in a super specific way, and just committing to the ridiculousness of it and the physicality of it was really fun,” he says. “I had a blast, dude.”

The pair’s star power shines throughout the 30-second spot that sees Stiller and Boone as Gary and John, heavily accented brothers and bandmates with “Dodgeball”-worthy mustaches. As with many of Stiller’s characters who become annoyed to their own detriment, his clear jealousy over Boone’s high falsetto and flapjack-like nature come to a cartoonish head.

The duo’s ’80s Europop band sings and dances to introduce Instacart’s latest in-app product innovation: Preference Picker. Starting with bananas, the new tool lets customers select their preferred ripeness — from “not ripe” to “almost ripe” to “ripe” — so shoppers can make better real-time decisions on their behalf. Hopefully, it means your “Heated Rivalry”-style smoothie will be safe from green bananas.

“It’s like, when you go into a supermarket, you can go and squeeze the fruit, make sure it’s the one you like, so I thought that this was a cool idea,” Stiller says. “And then for me, the jingle was so catchy and so, so ridiculous … It was a simple idea.”

Stiller’s Europop big brother character could fit into any one of his movies and is further boosted by Jonze’s meticulous attention to detail. The commercial was all shot on vintage tube cameras  — the same kind of camera used to shoot countless variety shows like the one it emulates — to “heighten the retro disco energy” of the comedic performance.

The 60-foot, glittering stage illuminated with orange and green LED lighting was built specifically for this ad, which of course, was littered with flips — more from Stiller than Boone, it should be noted.

“First of all, let me say, if anybody’s annoyed with his flipping, it’s flip envy,” Stiller says of the discourse around Boone’s onstage persona. “Nobody could do what he does. Come on. It’s crazy. I’ve seen it up close. It’s insane.”
Stiller also says he couldn’t deny Boone’s talent when they recorded the jingle together and he “heard him go off and do his crazy run.”
“He’s just so good, and it comes so naturally to him, and he’s so young, and it just kind of flows out,” Stiller adds about Boone.
Boone said in a press release that working on a Super Bowl commercial “blew (his) mind,” and that “adding Ben Stiller to the equation” was “diabolical.”

Aside from a couple of already released teasers (“Goals” and “Harmonizing”), Instacart is also releasing Spike Jonze’s director’s cut, a long-form version of the ad, that expands the musical rivalry into a full two-plus-minute narrative arc.
The 30-second spot will air during the Super Bowl on Sunday, Feb. 8, in the first quarter in the U.S. and the second quarter in Canada.

title: Susan Powter Makes Final Uber Eats Delivery with Al Roker on TODAY: ‘Everything Is Next’
summary: Susan Powter has closed a difficult chapter of her life with one last Uber Eats delivery — and she took along Al Roker to witness the poignant moment.
story: Susan Powter has closed a difficult chapter of her life with one last Uber Eats delivery — and she took along Al Roker to witness the poignant moment.

The ’90s fitness guru, known for her informercials urging Americans to “stop the insanity!” with her signature blond buzzcut, has been delivering food for Uber Eats for the past nine years while living paycheck to paycheck at a small apartment in Las Vegas.

A documentary released in November about Powter’s descent from fitness fame called “Stop the Insanity: Finding Susan Powter” has generated an extraordinary outpouring of support and opened a new world of possibilities for the 68-year-old mother of three. The film is available to watch on demand.
It has prompted her to leave her days of delivering for Uber Eats behind. She took Al along on Jan. 23 when she made the last of her deliveries in Las Vegas, which was shared on Jan. 28 on TODAY.
Al asked her if she ever thought she would have a chance to reinvent herself like this.
“I had lost hope,” she said. “I never thought about Susan Powter, ‘stop the insanity’ Susan Powter. I never thought about that. It was just was gone for many years. It was gone.”

Powter said on TODAY in November that a combination of bad business deals, lawsuits and a second divorce resulted in her declaring personal bankruptcy in 1995 after helming a fitness empire worth tens of millions.
She then disappeared from the spotlight for 30 years until the documentary, directed by Zeberiah Newman and executive produced by Jamie Lee Curtis, put a spotlight on her story.

“This is what I want people to really know,” she told Craig Melvin, Savannah Guthrie and Al on TODAY Jan. 28. “Possibility. A chance. Just being able to look forward to something is what really heals.”

Al’s ride with Powter also gave a glimpse into the inner workings of being a driver for a food delivery app. At one point, Powter picked up a Starbucks order from a commercial kitchen facility rather than an actual Starbucks. The facilities have been created as one-stop shops for delivery drivers for pickups.
She shared that she made $2.20 on the Starbucks delivery to an apartment. Al asked her if there was an aspect of making the deliveries that she would miss.
“No. I wouldn’t say ‘miss.’ I will never not acknowledge how grateful I am to have been able to do this,” she said.
The release of the documentary provided her with optimism when it was in short supply.

“I wrote seven books. I did nine videos. I did that work. And I thought it meant nothing,” she told Al. “When I first did the show, TODAY show, the movie wasn’t even out. And I remember saying, ‘All this love was out there, Susan.’
“And I’m seeing that in real time online. I’m hearing that. You’re sitting here. We’re doing this. That is the most healing thing for me.”

Powter’s final delivery was to a 26-year-old man named Tyler, who tipped her $5.23. Al made sure to inform Tyler who was actually delivering his food, considering he wasn’t even born when Powter was at the height of her fame.
“Google me,” Powter joked before telling Tyler that he had “such nice energy.”
“It’s how I was raised,” Tyler said. “It’s better to be kind. There’s not enough of that in the world.”
“You tell your mom and dad or whoever, ‘well done,’” Powter told him.
With her last delivery officially in the books, Powter shared with Al what she wants to do now.
“Everything is next,” she said. “Nothing has changed, but absolutely everything has. Absolutely everything has changed in my life because of possibility, hope, a chance.”
“I can do everything I did before,” she said. “I can do it again, which is rare to have another opportunity at my age, especially. And I can do it properly this time.”

Powter, who has been sharing her story on TikTok, said she envisions doing “books, audio, video, teaching wellness” and having an online presence. She also has had people sharing their own stories of hardship with her.

“Every day, comments. ‘I understand, I’m going through the same thing, I feel invisible, too,’” she said on TODAY. “You know, ‘I’m frightened, too, things didn’t work out that well for me, either.’ It is every day. And the love. I love the love. I’m so proud of and grateful for everything that’s happening.”
She also has no plans to rebuild her original ’90s brand, saying this version of her will be different.
“It’s everything,” she said about her new brand. “I’m so proud to say that. It’s everything.”
Powter still lives in her apartment in Las Vegas but said she plans to buy an RV and travel the country to engage with people about various issues, from fitness to aging to poverty.
“I’m going to go out to America, and I’m just going to accentuate the fabulousness,” she said. “I’m just going to go meet the fabulousness out there.”

Uber Eats also surprised her on TODAY by marking the end of her delivery chapter with a $10,000 donation to her favorite Las Vegas charity. The Just One Project is a nonprofit that fights food insecurity in the community.
“The dignity of being able to, at the very least, put food on the table, that is vitally important, so thank you,” Powter said about the gesture.
She left her day with Al exhilarated about what’s next in her life.
“Full of possibility and hope and excitement and gratitude,” she said.

title: Teddy Swims to Headline Super Bowl 60 Tailgate Concert
summary: The NFL has announced that Teddy Swims will headline the Super Bowl 60 Tailgate Concert.
story: Try not to lose control over the fact that Teddy Swims will perform at the Super Bowl 60 Tailgate Concert.

The NFL announced Jan. 28 the Grammy-nominated “Lose Control” singer will headline the show before the Super Bowl on Feb. 8 outside Levi’s Stadium in Santa Clara, California, before the big game between the New England Patriots and Seattle Seahawks.

Swims’ concert will stream live at 3:50 p.m. ET on Peacock and can be heard on 120 iHeart stations across the United States, as well as the iHeartRadio app. LaRussell, a rapper who hails from the Bay Area, will serve as Swims’ opener.

“The Super Bowl is one of those events I grew up watching with my dad and brothers and have always dreamed of being at and performing!” Swims said in a statement. “Coming from a football family I played and watched my whole life, the Super Bowl was a favorite past time for me and my family to get around and hang together. It’s an honor to be a part of it and kick off the game!”
The tailgate concert began with Super Bowl 54 and has featured acts like Miley Cyrus, The Chainsmokers, The Black Keys, Jason Derulo, Gwen Stefani and Post Malone.
After the tailgate concert, Green Day with perform at the Super Bowl opening ceremony, set to air live at 6 p.m. ET/ 3 p.m. PT on NBC, Telemundo, Peacock and Universo.

Before the game, Charlie Puth will sing the national anthem, while Brandi Carlile will sing “America the Beautiful” and Coco Jones will perform “Lift Every Voice and Sing.” Bad Bunny is slated to perform the halftime show.

title: What’s Happening With Harry Styles Tickets? Why Fans Are Calling Out the Presale
summary: Harry Styles fans are voicing their frustration after experiencing extended wait times and four-figure ticket prices due to demand during presale for the singer’s highly-anticipated “Together Together” tour
story: Harry Styles fans are voicing their frustration after experiencing extended wait times and four-figure ticket prices due to demand during presale for the singer’s highly-anticipated “Together Together” tour.

The pop singer revealed last week that he will embark on a tour this year after he releases his fourth album, “Kiss All The Time. Disco, Occasionally,” in March. Styles will travel to Amsterdam, London, São Paulo, Mexico City, Melbourne and Sydney to perform, and will also play a whopping 30 shows as part of a residency at Madison Square Garden in New York City.

But excitement to see the Grammy winner in person turned to frenzy when fans attempted to purchase presale tickets for the concerts. Those trying to access the American Express and artist presales posted screenshots on social media of them waiting in lengthy queues with over hundreds of thousands of fans hoping to score tickets.
The earliest presale for New York City, Amsterdam and London opened Jan. 26 and Melbourne and Sydney on Jan. 27, according to Styles’ website.

“Whatever it’s not like I wanted to see Harry styles,” one social media trying to buy for Madison Square Garden sarcastically tweeted on X and included screenshots of three queues all with more than 100,000 fans in them.

Another wrote, “17,000 people in line for presale for a tour where people have to travel across the US because the artist is only playing one city. Concert culture has gotten out of hand and live music is no longer accessible to those who it is supposed to inspire.”
Others said that their wait time was so long that tickets sold out while they were still in the queue.
“This is the WORST presale experience I’ve ever had,” one fan tweeted. “I really thought I had a chance to see Harry since I was  20k in line but they sold out in 30 minutes.”
The post included a message on Ticketmaster informing fans that the presale ended but they still have an opportunity to purchase tickets during the general sale.

General sale tickets will be available starting Friday, Jan. 30, for fans wanting to attend shows in Amsterdam, London, Melbourne, Sydney and New York City. For São Paulo and Mexico City fans, the general sale begins Jan. 28 and Jan. 29, respectively.

For some who managed to make it through the queue, the relief was short-lived when they were met with ticket prices exceeding $1,000. The AmEx presale featured platinum packages that accounted for some of the high prices.

Fans in the queue for New York City tickets were given a message from Ticketmaster: “Update: $50, $94.15 and $129.70 tickets are now limited, other options remain. Tickets for this event have been priced in advance by the tour from $50 — $1,184.40, including service fees. Ticket prices will not change during the presale or onsale. Price ranges do not apply to VIP packages. Tickets are subject to availability.”
The message also advised that wait times could exceed one hour.
A fan in the United Kingdom said that ticket prices in general have gotten out of hand.

“I’m a massive Harry Styles fan but we need to have a serious conversation about the absurd ticket prices some artists are now charging,” she said on X. “Makes music & entertainment completely inaccessible for a whole demographic of fans who don’t have hundreds to spend on a single ticket!”
Some poked fun at the situation, tweeting that Styles will be on stage dancing in an empty arena since “no one can afford to go.”
Ticketmaster has confirmed that demand for Styles’ New York City concerts was so high, it broke a record for the largest presale registrations in a single market, with 11.5 million sign-ups.

Ahead of the presale, Ticketmaster posted information on Instagram advising fans to look out for possible scams, like tickets posted on other sites before they are officially on sale. The post also included tips on ways to prepare for the sale, including joining the waiting room up to 30 minutes before tickets are available.

title: Is 'The Chronology of Water' Based on a True Story? What Lidia Yuknavitch Has Said About Her Film Directed by Kristen Stewart
summary: Kristen Stewart directs "The Chronology of Water," a film based on the true life and memoir of Lidia Yuknavitch.
story: Kristen Stewart directs “The Chronology of Water,” an intimate drama based on author and teacher Lidia Yuknavitch’s 2011 memoir of the same name.
The film follows Lidia, portrayed by Imogen Poots, a promising swimmer who struggles at home with an abusive father and complacent mother in the '80s.
As her athletic dreams take a different turn, she is faced with love, loss, addiction and self-destructive choices that eventually leads her to discover her voice and healing through writing.

Stewart first encountered the memoir in 2017, she shared in a statement, “And from the very first page I felt its electric current — this jagged, nonlinear journey through trauma and memory was unlike anything I’d ever read.”
She noted that after 40 pages, she had “such a physical reaction that I put the book down, grabbed my phone, and told my team, ‘I need to speak to the person who wrote this.’”

What drew her to the story, Stewart said, was its fragmentation, explaining, “Yuknavitch doesn’t give you a tidy narrative, but instead hands you the pieces of a life in shards, demanding you assemble them yourself. That act of reconstruction — of watching a story break and then choosing to stitch it back together — became the beating heart of why I knew this had to be my first film.”
In a December 2025 interview with Vogue, Yuknavitch shared that she had yet to see the movie but when she saw Poots as her “all the hairs on my body” stood up.
“Not because we can look like each other or anything like that, but just because I can see that she has an extraordinary ability to inhabit emotional intensity and a whole range,” she said.
Read on to learn more about Lidia Yuknavitch, the real-life woman who inspired “The Chronology of Water” directed by Kristen Stewart.
Lidia Yuknavitch Was a Promising Swimmer

“The Chronology of Water” shows Lidia’s early swimming days, a true athlete and good at the sport. The film shows her competitively swimming and getting offered partial college scholarships for her skills.
Yuknavitch began swimming at the age of 4, she recalled in a 2018 interview, and began competing just two years later.

“What swimming meant all through my adolescence was freedom from the house of father. All my mornings and afternoons were small salvations, all those hours and lap after lap away from home and family, two words that nearly killed me,” she wrote in a personal essay for LitHub. “I didn’t care about winning medals or my team or even my name in lights on giant digitalized scoreboards. I cared about the away from him. I cared about how within water, a body could be a body, a body could even be, dare I think it, mine.”
She Was a Victim of Abuse
In her memoir, Yuknavitch details how her father would verbally, sexually and physically abuse her and her sister while her mom, who suffered from alcoholism, wouldn't always intervene.
In her personal essay, she recalled how her father would shame her if she didn't perform well during her swimming competitions. The physical hits, she wrote, came later.

"Shame was a lesson that swam deeply in my blood. You know, even at six years old I understood a blow would have been preferable," she wrote. "So when the blows came later in life, I didn’t flinch. I’d already learned to take what was worse."
Trying to escape him, her father refused to let her go away to college until, she wrote, her mother stepped up.

“A week later, when the papers came to sign, my father was at work. My mother signed them. I remember watching her hand, a little stunned. She had beautiful handwriting. Then she put them in the envelope, grabbed her car keys, and told me C’mawn. In her southern drawl liquor voice," she wrote in her memoir.
"In her real estate station wagon. Driving to the post oﬃce with her and watching her drop my freedom into the blue metal mouth of the mailbox — I almost loved her.”
Her First Baby Was Stillborn

Among her biggest heartbreaks was the death of her daughter Lily who was stillborn. She shared in an interview with The Lit Pub that she decided to open her book with the story about her daughter “because that is the body event that ‘opened’ me. I mean it broke me. Utterly. But it broke me OPEN.”

“I became a writer from that experience. Not instantly, in the moment I went fairly insane, as I wrote about,” she said. “But later. The first thing that came out of me when my wits and emotions settled back toward something bearable was writing. As it turns out, there was a lot in there ... I think I have many, many books to say.”
She's Struggled With Mental Health and Drug Addiction
Yuknavitch shared that she struggled with “episodes of severe depression” since she was a child, she told Street Roots in 2015.

“Sometimes the waves go away, sometimes they don’t. Sometimes I’m on medication to help navigate the waves,” she said. “I’d say abuse and anger and grief took root in me young enough that it will likely be with me for life in some form.”
She was addicted to heroin as a young adult, sharing that she began using again after her daughter died.

“Kicked again after a brief period of psychosis and homelessness. I think mental health and addiction and surviving abuse and deep grief are real places that some people go,” she told the publication. “They are dark places, like the bottom of the ocean. Some people don’t ever come back up. For whatever reasons, I was able to come back up, come back to life, more than once, and so I have vowed to bring something with me — the responsibility to help other people afflicted by the darkness.”
She's Been Married Three Times
Yuknavitch was married to her first husband, Philip, when their daughter was stillborn. At the time, she was in college, the film depicts.
Her second husband was the late David Eugene Crowe. She details their relationship woes in “The Chronology of Water” and “Reading the Waves.”
In an interview with OPB, she described their “demise as a couple” as “very dramatic, difficult and traumatic.”
She is currently married to film producer Andy Mingo and they have a son named Miles.

“In my first marriage I was a confused ball of nuclear rage and creative fire without a form. In my second marriage I was insane with grief and numbed myself with laughter and every excess imaginable, including writing,” Yuknavitch told The Lit Pub. “In my third marriage I am learning what being is.”
She Is a Bestselling Author
“In 1983 my daughter died the day she was born. From her I became a writer,” reads her bio on her website.
Aside from “The Chronology of Water,” she’s also written “Dora: A Headcase,” “The Small Backs of Children,” “The Book of Joan,” “Thrust” and “The Misfit’s Manifesto,” among others.
She Continues to Create Art
Yuknavitch lives in Oregon and continues to express herself creatively.

“I haven’t been writing for over a year because I have some personal life stuff going on, but hundreds of paintings are coming out of me, so I’m very curious about that,” she told Vogue in December 2025. “I’m having to talk to them and ask them what they’re about. Although last week, for the first time in a while, some novel stuff started coming out of me, so apparently I have the very, very beginnings of a novel going, and once they start coming, there’s nothing I can do about it.”

title: Melissa Gilbert Breaks Social Media Silence Amid Husband's Sex Abuse Charges: 'Extraordinarily Difficult Time'
summary: Melissa Gilbert has spoken out publicly for the first time as her husband Timothy Busfield faces child sex abuse charges in New Mexico.
story: Melissa Gilbert has spoken out publicly for the first time as her husband Timothy Busfield faces child sex abuse charges in New Mexico.
The author and actor thanked her supporters during what she called an "extraordinarily difficult time" in an Instagram post on Jan. 26 on the account for her Modern Prairie brand.

Her post came six days after a New Mexico judge ordered the release of Busfield from jail in Albuquerque while he awaits trial on two counts of criminal sexual contact of a minor and one count of child abuse.

"I’m sending you all my love and gratitude during this extraordinarily difficult time," she wrote. "Not only for Tim, me and our family, but in the collective heaviness so many of us seem to be carrying right now. Add an unexpected storm to the mix, and it can all feel like a bit too much."

"This season has reminded me, very clearly, how important it is to slow down, prioritize what truly matters, and allow ourselves moments of rest," she continued. "Stepping back from the noise, the news, and even our daily responsibilities from time to time gives us space to recharge, reflect, and find our center again."
The former "Little House on the Prairie" star thanked fans for the support they have shown her and Busfield.

"Thank you for helping me to feel safer, more grounded, and deeply held by this extraordinary community of women here at Modern Prairie," she wrote. "I’ll be easing back into things thoughtfully and with care - moving forward one step at a time. More to come, and so much gratitude always."
Gilbert deleted her personal Instagram account after the allegations against her husband surfaced.

During Busfield's first in-person court appearance on Jan. 20, Gilbert, 61, could be seen in the courtroom crying in relief when a judge ruled that the Emmy-winning former star of "Thirtysomething" and "The West Wing" should be released from jail on his own recognizance while he faces the charges. Busfield, 68, appeared at the hearing in shackles and an orange jumpsuit.
Gilbert had also previously submitted a letter of support to the court, saying her husband “has the strongest moral compass of any human I have ever known.”
“He has dedicated his spiritual self to always being of service to others. He starts every day with kindness and compassion,” she said.

The charges stem from the parents of two male child actors telling Albuquerque police that Busfield inappropriately touched them on multiple occasions on the set of the Fox series "The Cleaning Lady," according to the criminal complaint. Busfield acted and directed on the show.
Busfield has denied the allegations.
Busfield turned himself in to authorities on Jan. 13 after an arrest warrant had been issued.

“He wants to turn himself in because he wants to clear his name and reputation,” his attorney, Larry Stein, told NBC News at the time. “He didn’t do anything wrong. These accusations are false as the investigator from the independent law firm found.”

title: Howard Stern Says Renewing SiriusXM Contract ‘Feels Great’
summary: In conversation with Al Roker on TODAY Jan. 27, Howard Stern said renewing his SiriusXM contract for 3 more years "feels great."
story: Howard Stern is excited to remain at SiriusXM.

The legendary radio personality appeared on TODAY on Jan. 27 to help Al Roker celebrate his 30th anniversary on the show, but took a moment to touch on his three-year contract extension that he inked back in December to remain on SiriusXM.
“By the way, Howard, congratulations,” Al said. “I understand you just signed a new contract. You’re going to be there for a little while longer. How does that feel?”
“It feels great,” he said during the interview that was simulcast on “The Howard Stern Show” on SiriusXM.
Stern, 72, then compared it to Al appearing in the “Sharknado” movie series.

“I said to people, it must be like when Al signed up to do ‘Sharknado.’ That was the greatest thing I ever saw you do, when you appeared in ‘Sharknado,’” he joked. “When I signed that contract at SiriusXM, I said to myself, ‘This is how Al felt.’”
He then asked Al to recite his line from one of the campy movies, prompting Al to admit, “I don’t remember.”
Stern and Al have plenty of history. Al has been a guest on Stern’s show 11 times over the years and they were both on WNBC in New York back in the 1980s.

Stern moved to SiriusXM and satellite radio in 2006. Amid rumors Stern was going to retire, he and Andy Cohen played a prank last September, in which the Bravo star opened Stern’s show and told listeners he was taking over the program.
After he signed his most recent contract, Stern said he still had plenty of gas left in the tank.
“I still do love being on the radio. I think the show is better than ever, I really do believe that in my heart,” he said on his show.

title: 52 Books We Can't Wait to Read in 2026
summary: These are the books of 2026 that we can't wait to read.
story: A new year brings new reads — lots and lots of them.

Already, TODAY has hosted two lookaheads for 2026 reads. And on her "Open Book with Jenna" podcast, Jenna Bush Hager and guest Isaac Fitzgerald discussed the books they were looking forward to reading in the new year.
His picks included "Lost Lambs" by Madeline Cash and "Rest of Our Lives" by Ben Markowitz. Jenna, meanwhile, said she couldn't wait to read Chloe Benjamin's "Under Story."
Below, find some books to look forward to in 2026, but far from the only books.
January
"Homeschooled" by Stefan Merrill Block

The first Read With Jenna pick of the year is a memoir by Stefan Merrill Block. In the book, he describes the years his mother pulled him out of school for her homegrown curriculum, a combination of smothering and neglect.
“‘Homeschooled’ is a beautiful debut memoir. I loved its raw honesty and the very American story of one little boy growing up in a family where love is obvious but so is dysfunction,” Jenna says.
More books to read in January 2026:

"Dandelion Is Dead" by Rosie Storey (Jan. 13): A woman goes on a dating app posing as her larger-than-life — and very much dead — sister. Read an excerpt here. "Scavengers" by Katherine Boland (Jan. 13): A mother and daughter go out in search of treasure in the style of Forrest Fenn's real-life treasure."The Future Saints" by Ashley Winstead (Jan. 20): Perfect for the music lover, a music executive stumbles upon a band of astronomical talent then has to contend with them against their own struggles.  "Half His Age" by Jennette McCurdy (Jan. 20): Jennette McCurdy follows her hit memoir up with a book about a 17-year-old having an affair with her creative writing teacher."The Infamous Gilberts" by Angela Tomaski (Jan. 20): Open the door to a dilapidated mansion and follow a truly dysfunctional British family over the years. "All the Little Houses" by May Cobb (Jan. 20): Author of “The Hunting Wives” returns with another book about a Texas friend group disrupted by a new arrival, this time in the 1980s."The Seven Daughters of Dupree" by Nikesha Elise Williams (Jan. 27): Seven generations of one Black American family and how history reverberates — they might not know how they’re connected, but we will."Vigil" by George Saunders (Jan. 27): On the evening of a wealthy oil mogul's death, multiple spirits come to try to ferry him toward enlightenment."We Who Have No Gods" by Liza Anderson (Jan. 27): Nonmagical heroine Vic insists on chaperoning her young brother, a witch, to his magical school and secret society, encountering plenty of monsters along the way.

title: Craig Melvin Launches a New Podcast, ‘Glass Half Full.’ See the Trailer
summary: TODAY’s Craig Melvin is launching a new podcast, “Glass Half Full,” in which he sits down with sports and entertainment figures. Watch the trailer.
story: TODAY’s Craig Melvin is taking celebrity guests — and viewers —inside his home to the place he feels most comfortable and even most vulnerable: his basement bar.

On Feb. 3, Craig will officially launch his own video podcast, “Glass Half Full,” which will see the TODAY co-anchor sit down with notable figures in sports and entertainment for candid conversations.
“I’ve always been fascinated by what shapes people,” Craig says in the trailer, which dropped Jan. 27. “The setbacks, the breakthroughs, the moments that really change everything.”
As Craig explains in the trailer, each episode will open with the same question: “Would you consider yourself a glass half full or glass half empty kind of person?”
Choosing to name the podcast “Glass Half Full” came from Craig’s own answer to that question.
“At the end we decided to land on how I view the world, how I view my life,” he said. “There’s a lot of bad that happens. There are a lot of terrible things that we have to talk about every day.
“But one of the things that I’ve discovered over the last decade or so is that there’s a lot of good out there.”

The trailer previews all the upcoming guests who will sit down for a toast and conversation with Craig, including Shaquille O’Neal, Shonda Rhimes, Carmelo Anthony, Rich Paul, Jim Gaffigan, Roy Wood Jr., Regina Hall, Malcolm Gladwell, Mellody Hobson, Dawn Staley, Scott Galloway and Ilia Malinin.
While Craig is no stranger to interviewing fascinating people, the appeal of the podcast is getting to “go deep,” he said.

“These really interesting people. They’ll say something, and if we were on the show, I couldn’t follow up, because we’ve got to hit the commercial break,” he said. “Here in my basement we can talk about that for five, 10 minutes. You say something funny or weird, we can really go there.”
“Glass Half Full” will officially launch on Tuesday, Feb. 3. Each episode will be available on the TODAY YouTube channel and wherever you get your podcasts.

title: Alex Honnold Was Paid an ‘Embarrassingly Small’ Amount For Netflix Special, He Says
summary: How much was Alex Honnold paid to climb the Taiplei 101 skyscraper? Inside the "an embarrassingly small amount" he received.
story: Alex Honnold hit paydirt when he climbed to the top of the 101-story, 1,667-foot Taipei 101 skyscraper. What he apparently didn’t hit was a huge payday.
Honnold, 40, thrilled onlookers and audiences who watched the event on Netflix’s “Skyscraper Live” on Jan. 24, but he says he didn’t get paid a lot of money to do it.
“I’m not gonna say. It’s an embarrassing amount,” he told The New York Times in an interview published two days before he scaled the skyscraper, when asked how much he would be paid.

“Actually, if you put it in the context of mainstream sports, it’s an embarrassingly small amount,” he continued. “You know, Major League Baseball players get like $170 million contracts. Like, someone you haven’t even heard of and that nobody cares about.”
TODAY.com reached out to both Honnold and Netflix for comment, but has not gotten a response.
Honnold, who appeared in the Academy Award-winning documentary “Free Solo,” played it coy when asked if this was his biggest payday.
“Maybe. It’s less than my agent aspired to,” he said.
Honnold said he would "do it for free," however.
"If there was no TV program and the building gave me permission to go do the thing, I would do the thing because I know I can, and it’d be amazing," he said.
"I’m not getting paid to climb the building. I’m getting paid for the spectacle. I’m climbing the building for free.”
While the adventure had his wife on the edge of her seat, Honnold was ecstatic to say he completed the challenge.
“It’s kind of like a happy tired. I know I’m going to cross the finish line. I feel great,” he said in an interview that aired on TODAY on Jan. 26.

title: Nigella Lawson Replaces Prue Leith on ‘Great British Bake Off’: ‘Giddily Grateful’
summary: Just days after Prue Leith announced her exit from “The Great British Bake Off,” we now know who will be stepping into her shoes: TV chef Nigella Lawson.
story: Just days after Prue Leith announced her exit from “The Great British Bake Off,” viewers now know who will be stepping into her colorful shoes on the show.
On Jan. 26, the official Instagram account for the baking show revealed that renowned cook and food writer Nigella Lawson will soon join the show as a judge.
“We’re delighted to announce that Nigella Lawson is joining The Great British Bake Off as our new judge!” the announcement read.
The post also included a statement from Lawson, who expressed her excitement over her new role.

“I’m uncharacteristically rather lost for words right now! Of course it’s daunting to be following in the footsteps of Prue Leith and Mary Berry before her, great dames both, but I’m also bubbling with excitement,” she wrote.
Lawson described the baking show as a “National Treasure” and noted that it was a “huge honour to be entrusted with it.”
“I’m just thrilled to be joining the team and all the new bakers to come, I wish the marvellous Prue all the best, and am giddily grateful for the opportunity!” Lawson concluded.
Lawson took to the comments section to reiterate her joy, writing,  “Thank you, thank you, thank you — I can’t wait to enter the Tent of Dreams!”
Leith also weighed in, writing, “I was so hoping it would be Nigella! Brilliant choice 🙌.”

In a press release announcing Lawson’s appointment as a judge, Leith also applauded the show’s decision, writing, “I’m thrilled that Nigella is to experience brilliant Bake Off. She’s sassy, fun and she knows her onions — and her croissants, cake and crumble.”
On Jan. 21, the 86-year-old restaurateur announced she was stepping down as a judge of the show, a role she held for nine seasons.

“Bake Off has been a fabulous part of my life for the last nine years, I have genuinely loved it and I’m sure I’ll miss working with my fellow judge Paul, Alison and Noel and the teams at Love Productions and Channel 4,” she wrote. “But now feels like the right time to step back (I’m 86 for goodness sake!), there’s so much I’d like to do, not least spend summers enjoying my garden.”

title: Alex Honnold’s Wife’s 5-Word Reaction to His 101-Floor Climb
summary: Alex Honnold's explains what she felt watching her husband climb the 1,667-foot Taipei 101 skyscraper.
story: Onlookers and viewers were left breathless while watching Alex Honnold climb the 1,667-foot Taipei 101 skyscraper over the weekend without the aid of a rope, harness or any other safety equipment.

Count his wife, Sanni McCandless Honnold, among those who were in awe that he scaled the world’s 11th tallest building — although she was definitely relieved not to be the one trying to pull off climbing the 101 stories.
“I was definitely pretty enlivened by the energy of the crowd,” she said while appearing with her husband at a press conference afterward.

“It was truly wild to walk out of the building and just see so many people. And I was telling someone that when you really love someone and you think that they might be stressed, you’re kind of like, ‘I wish I could take their place.’ You know, I wish I could take any of their stress away. But in this case, I was like, ‘Thank God I’m not him!’”

Honnold, 40, is a famed climber known for the Oscar-winning film “Free Solo.” In the documentary, Honnold became the first person to free solo El Capitan, a 3,000-foot granite wall in Yosemite National Park.
The latest challenge was witnessed by crowds on the ground and inside Taipei 101, as well as viewers who tuned in live to watch the 95-minute adventure on Netflix.
While many people watching her husband may have chewed their fingernails down to the cuticles, Sanni Honnold said her bundle of nerves eventually dissipated.

“I knew the second he left the ground it would all just kind of, not fade away, but get quieter, kind of be a little bit more of an internal experience, and then just be joyful,” she said. “And, so, I was really happy when it just started. There wasn’t any waiting. He got to do what he wanted to do.”
Alex Honnold, who checked in with his wife while she was on the 60th floor and greeted her once he got to the top of the skyscraper, meanwhile, basked in the glory of his accomplishment.
“It’s amazing. I’m sure I’ll be glowing for days,” he said during the press conference afterward.
Honnold thrilled fans by not using hands at certain junctures and hanging in the air before he snapped a selfie once he made it to the top of the edifice.
“It’s kind of like a happy tired. I know I’m going to cross the finish line. I feel great,” he said in an interview that aired on TODAY on Jan. 26.
“It’s a lot less scary to stand on the top of the building than it is to climb the side of the building, that’s for sure,” he also said. “The whole experience was really pretty amazing, though.”
